search.slidetext: begin
press your keyboard’s “a” key to initiate audio on each slide. (autoplay is not accessible because it can compete with screen reader audio!) back continue

press your keyboard’s “a” key to initiate audio on each slide. (autoplay is not accessible because it can compete with screen reader audio!) back continue objectives • identify two accessibility laws for e-learning settings: the americans with disabilities act (ada) and section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 • recognize the world wide web consortium’s web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) • classify level a, level aa, and level aaa levels of accessibility • identify types of assistive technology • identify the county of monterey’s level of accessibility • summarize the reasons why e-learning should be accessibility-friendly
back continue

incorrect incorrect. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct correct. wcag stands for web content accessibility guidelines. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue what does wcag stand for? (choose one response). web content approved guidelines web content approved guidelines web content approved guidelines web content approved guidelines web content approved guidelines web content approved guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web content accessibility guidelines web creation approach guidelines web creation approach guidelines web creation approach guidelines web creation approach guidelines web creation approach guidelines web creation approach guidelines

incorrect incorrect. try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again correct correct. two accessibility laws for e-learning settings are the americans with disabilities act, or ada, and section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue select two (2) accessibility laws for e-learning settings. the americans with disabilities act (ada) the americans with disabilities act (ada) the americans with disabilities act (ada) the americans with disabilities act (ada) the americans with disabilities act (ada) the americans with disabilities act (ada) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973
back continue classifying the three levels of accessibility • level a – moderately accessible • level aa – works with most assistive technology • level aaa – works with all assistive technology
back continue types of assistive technology used in e-learning settings • text-to-speech (example: jaws screen reader) • speech-to-text (example: dragon naturallyspeaking speech recognition)
back continue locating the three levels of accessibility in web content accessibility guidelines

incorrect incorrect. try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again correct correct. you correctly matched each level of accessibility with its description. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue match each level of accessibility to its correct description. level a an e-learning course is accessible level aa an e-learning course works with most assistive technology level aaa an e-learning course works with all assistive technology

incorrect incorrect. try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again correct correct. jaws screen reader is an example of an assistive technology and an example of a text-to-speech technology. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue select one (1) answer from the options below. jaws screen reader is an example of a _____________________. speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology

incorrect incorrect. try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again correct correct. dragon naturallyspeaking is an example of an assistive technology and an example of a speech-to-text technology. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue select one (1) answer from the options below. dragon naturallyspeaking is an example of a _____________________. text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology text-to-speech assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology speech-to-text assistive technology
back continue the county of monterey • adheres to level aa
back continue why e-learning courses should be accessibility-friendly • ethical reasons • legal reasons

incorrect incorrect. try again! try again try again try again try again try again try again correct correct. e-learning courses should be accessible to all individuals. please continue. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false select true or false for the statement below: e-learning courses should be accessible to most individuals.
begin

don't use: italics and serif fonts font sizes that are too small or too large more than two different fonts in your course text in pictures, except for logos the color pairings red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text time limits a limit for the number of times learners may take your course continue back current accessibility standards use: bold text and sans-serif fonts different fonts to distinguish headings from normal text descriptive links alt text for images the colors black and white mainly and to emphasize important text contrast captions for any audio elements included in your course tables and descriptive table headings

four categories of mental and physical involvement continue back { source: reiser, r. a., & dempsey, j. v. (2018). trends and issues in instructional design and technology. new york: pearson. }
sh vision involvement continue back
hearing involvement continue back
mobility involvement continue back
cognitive involvement continue back
four categories of mental and physical involvement continue back

press your keyboard’s “a” key to initiate audio on each slide. (autoplay is not accessible because it can compete with screen reader audio!) back continue

scenario 2: a different learner, phil, is deaf in both ears. keeping this in mind, what is the best way for you to design your e-learning course to accommodate phil? continue back scenario 1: one of your learners, kimberly, has complete color blindness. keeping this in mind, what is the best way for you to design your e-learning course to accommodate kimberly? imagine you are designing an e-learning course; read the following scenarios and spend 5-10 minutes brainstorming possible solutions.

continue back imagine you are designing an e-learning course; read the following scenarios and spend 5-10 minutes brainstorming possible solutions. scenario 4: another learner, jasmine, has arthritis in both hands. keeping this in mind, what is the best way for you to design your e-learning course to accommodate jasmine? scenario 3: another learner, mohammad, is epileptic. keeping this in mind, what is the best way for you to design your e-learning course to accommodate mohammad?

for scenarios 3 & 4: to accommodate mohammad, make sure you have planned to avoid the use of flashy elements (epileptic individuals should not be exposed to more than three flashes per second, although some epileptic individuals require more strict rules). to accommodate jasmine, make sure you have planned to ensure that jasmine can interact with your course from her keyboard (i.e. without having to use a mouse). continue back for scenarios 1 & 2: to accommodate kimberly, perhaps you have decided to use mainly black and white for your text elements and background colors, or you have decided to use only color bind safe colors (i.e. you will not pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red). to accommodate phil, make sure you have planned to include captions and/or on-screen text for all audio. thank you for brainstorming some solutions; your learners will appreciate your thoughtfulness.
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide text alternatives accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide time-based media alternatives accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide adaptable content accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide distinguishable content accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide keyboard accessibility accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide enough time accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: avoid causing seizures accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide navigability accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide readable/understandable text accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide predictability accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide input assistance accessibility-friendly design
continue back web content accessibility guideline: provide compatibility accessibility-friendly design
press your keyboard’s “a” key to initiate audio on each slide. (autoplay is not accessible because it can compete with screen reader audio!) back continue

post test begin back directions: we are nearing the end of the course. please answer the following questions to the best of your ability. there are ten questions, and you can review your results upon completion of the test. you can select begin to begin the test, or select back to review all you have learned in this course prior to beginning the test, if you feel more comfortable doing so.

incorrect incorrect. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct correct. current standards for accessible e-learning design include the following: use descriptive links, use alt text for images, do not pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text, use contrast, include captions for any audio elements included in your course, do not use time limits, and do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. continue continue continue continue continue continue select current standards for accessible e-learning design. use descriptive links. use descriptive links. use descriptive links. use descriptive links. use descriptive links. use descriptive links. use alt text for images. use alt text for images. use alt text for images. use alt text for images. use alt text for images. use alt text for images. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. pair the colors red and green, blue and green, and yellow and red to emphasize important text. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use low contrast between foreground and background elements. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. use captions for any audio elements included in your course. set time limits for learners. set time limits for learners. set time limits for learners. set time limits for learners. set time limits for learners. set time limits for learners. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course. do not limit the number of times a learner may take your course.

in this module, you learned about… two accessibility laws for e-learning settings: the americans with disabilities act (ada) and section 508 of the rehabilitation act of 1973 the world wide web consortium’s web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) level a, level aa, and level aaa levels of accessibility types of assistive technology the county of monterey’s level of accessibility (aa) reasons why e-learning should be accessibility-friendly current accessibility standards the four categories of mental and physical involvement each of w3’s twelve level aa web content accessibility guidelines (wcag) continue back
exit course. spend a few minutes learning about storyline’s accessibility features: storyline’s accessibility features 1. 2.
